title: Maritime Piracy & its Effect on Vessel Traffic in West Africa
text:
Background

Piracy is costly
International Maritime Bureau estimates: $1-9 billion per year
UNODC, report by Stable Seas 2021, piracy costs in the Gulf of Guinea region

Direct costs (Random paid, losses from stolen oil and goods, spending on counter piracy efforts, prosecutions and legal effort): $200-300 million per years

What about indirect costs on trade?
More salient question after the recent supply-chain problem & its effect on trade disruption

Research Question

Consequences of maritime piracy
How does maritime piracy influence international trade (narrower: vessel traffic) ?

title: Maritime Piracy & its Effect on Vessel Traffic in West Africa
text:
Indirect costs of piracy?

Most accounts of estimates anecdotal & “guesstimate” mainly due to lack of data
But the availability of Automatic Identification System (AIS) data can be immensely helpful

For instance, recent work by economists Sandkamp1, Stamer & Yang (2021): daily ship data
We build on this work by using more fine-grained 2-hourly data to understand ship traffic behavior in the event of piracy
Work in progress: comment/questions will be immensely helpful!

title: Maritime Piracy & its Effect on Vessel Traffic in West Africa
section: Is there a systematic association between piracy events & illegal Fishing?
text:
Is there a systematic association between piracy events & illegal Fishing?

Past works: Illegal fishing & piracy correlated
Foreign trawlers –> Deplete fishery –> Local fishers turn to piracy (Ploch et al. 2011; Weir 2009; Desai and Shambaugh 2021)
Seemingly plausible, but lacks evidence (Denton and Harris 2021; Jesperson 2022)

title: Maritime Piracy & its Effect on Vessel Traffic in West Africa
text:
Local milieu
Local illegal fishers –> turn to piracy –> when there is a constrain on illegal fishing & near target-rich high shipping areas

title: Maritime Piracy & its Effect on Vessel Traffic in West Africa
text:
Hypotheses
H1: Piracy incidents are more likely to occur in areas where illegal fishing has declined.

H2: Piracy incidents are more likely to occur in areas with high commercial vessel traffic.

H3 (Interaction): Piracy incidents are more likely to occur in areas with high vessel traffic and a decline in illegal fishing.

title: Maritime Piracy & its Effect on Vessel Traffic in West Africa
text:
Conclusion

Illegal fishing is associated with piracy, but not simple correlation
In Indonesia, locals engaged in illegal fishing, turn to piracy when IUUF catch is constrained
Without addressing community-level grievances, enforcement that effectively restricts IUU fishing can increase sea-piracy
